contentrichtext.text: '''Francisco de Bobadilla''' was a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[colony|colonial]] administrator. Member of the [[Order of Calatrava]], in 1499, de Bobadilla was appointed to succeed [[Christopher Columbus]] as the second [[governor]] of the Indies, [[Spain]]'s new territories in [[Americas|America]], by [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|King Ferdinand]] and [[Isabella I of Castile|Queen Isabella]]. Upon his arrival at [[Santo Domingo]], [[Hispaniola]] in August 1500, de Bobadilla upheld accusations of mismanagement made against Columbus, and had Columbus sent back to Spain in chains.<ref>{{Citation |title=Admiral of the Ocean Sea: A Life of Christopher Columbus |year=1942 |last=Morison |first=Samuel Eliot |publisher=Little, Brown and Co. |location=Boston |page=571 }}.</ref> In 1502, he was replaced as governor of Hispaniola by [[Nicolás de Ovando y Cáceres]]. He died {{OldStyleDate|July 11|1502|July 1}} during a [[North Atlantic tropical cyclone|hurricane]] that wrecked 20 vessels of the 31-ship convoy, including the flagship, ''El Dorado'', in the [[Mona Passage]] returning to Spain. Among the surviving ships was the ''Aguja'', the weakest ship of the convoy and which carried the gold Columbus was owed—spurring accusations that Columbus magically invoked the storm out of vengeance.<ref>Morison, Samuel Eliot (1942), p. 590.</ref> ==See also== * [[List of Viceroys of New Spain]] * [[Viceroyalty of New Spain]] * [[Pre-1600 Atlantic hurricane seasons]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Bobadilla, Francisco | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1502 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bobadilla, Francisco}} [[Category:15th-century births]] [[Category:1502 deaths]] [[Category:Spanish conquistadors]] [[Category:Aragonese conquistadors]] [[Category:Colonial governors of Santo Domingo]] {{Spain-bio-stub}}
